bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean and Albert E. Truby, September 1, 1944

div1.p: Hench describes receiving Reed's “New Year's Eve letter,” in which Reed described his thoughts on the transmission of yellow fever by mosquitoes.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean and Albert E. Truby, September 1, 1944
div1.opener:

1 September 1944
General Jefferson R. Kean
2804 “N” Street, N.W.
Washington 7, D. C.
and
General Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
My dear General Kean:
div1.p:
As you know, Walter Reed's “New Year's Eve letter” is very
widely quoted, and is a lovely letter. I have been anxious actually to
see it and get a photographic copy of it. Blossom Reed loaned me the
letter and I have had copies made. The first part of the letter and the
last part are missing. Apparently, they contained personal matters,
and these parts were not saved. I thought you would like to have a photo-
graphic copy of the letter. It begins with the part I have marked #1,
and proceeds as I have marked.

Among Mrs. Reed's letters and papers were several interesting
photographs. I had a copy made of one, which I enclose. Obviously, it
was taken at Camp Lazear. Do you recognize any of the figures? The
officer leaning against the tree looks to me like Doctor Cooke. You will
notice a tent on the horizon, between the tree and the wagon, also another
tent faintly on the horizon, on the left of the picture. Do you suppose
that some of the men in the foreground are patients? And, I wondered
whether the distinguished looking man in the derby might be Doctor
Albertini. I would appreciate whatever identifications you can make. I
have sent a copy to Moran, also. Incidentally, Moran and his wife are
about to go to Rochester on account of his wife's health. I am so sorry
that I can not be there to act as his host.
div1.closer:
Always sincerely yours, PHILIP S. HENCH, Lt. Col., M.C.
Chief of Medical Service Encl.
P.S. To Gen. Kean: Anticipating the reconstruction of the interior of
the little building at Camp Lazear to make it look
as much like it did in the old days as possible, I

To: Gen. J. R. Kean

am anxious, as you know, to find out what kind of a stove might have been
in that building. General Truby thinks it might have been a Sibley stove.
What do you think of this idea?
